SCONJ.content: Definition A subordinating conjunction is a conjunction that links constructions by making one of them a constituent of the other. The subordinating conjunction typically marks the incorporated constituent which has the status of a subordinate clause. Subordinating conjunctions in Chinese include all markers of subordinate clauses, including conditional clauses, purpose clauses, etc. In paired clauses where both clauses are marked by a conjunctive word and the first is subordinate to the second, we treat the conjunctive word in the first clause as SCONJ, whereas the one in the second, main clause as an adverb (ADV) (e.g., é›–ç„¶/SCONJ... å¯æ˜¯/ADV... / suÄ«rÃ¡n... kÄ›shÃ¬... "Although... however..."). Examples - å¦‚æœ / rÃºguÇ’ "if", çš„è©± / dehuÃ  "if" - é›–ç„¶ / suÄ«rÃ¡n "although" - å„˜ç®¡ / jÇnguÇn "even if" - ç„¡è«– / wÃºlÃ¹n "no matter" - "in order to": ä¾† / lÃ¡i, å» / qÃ¹, ä»¥ / yÇ - ä¼¸å‡ºä½ çš„æ‰‹ä¾†çœ‹çœ‹ / shÄ“n chÅ« nÇ de shÇ’u lÃ¡i kÃ nkan "stretch out your hand (in order) to take a look"

DET.content: Definition Determiners are words that modify nouns or noun phrases and express the reference of the noun phrase in context. Note that Chinese does not traditionally define determiners as a separate word class, but categorizes them as pronouns and/or adjectives. For this reason, in the UD framework some words in Chinese may function as determiners and be tagged DET in one syntactic context (i.e., when modifying a noun), and as pronouns (tagged PRON) when behaving as a nominal or the head of a nominal phrase. Examples - Demonstrative determiners - é€™ / zhÃ¨ "this", é€™äº› / zhÃ¨xiÄ“ "these", æ­¤ / cÇ "this", é‚£ / nÃ  "that", é‚£äº› / nÃ xiÄ“ "those", è©² / gÄi "that" - Possessive determiner - å…¶ / qÃ­ "his/her/its; their", æœ¬ / bÄ›n "our" - Quantifying determiners - Definite: å„ / gÃ¨ "every", è«¸ / zhÅ« "every", æ¯ / mÄ›i "every", æ•´ / zhÄ›ng "whole", å…¨ / quÃ¡n "whole", å…¨éƒ¨ / quÃ¡nbÃ¹ "all", ä¸€åˆ‡ / yÄ«qiÃ¨ "all", æ‰€æœ‰ / suÇ’yÇ’u "all" - Indefinite: ä»»ä½• / rÃ¨nhÃ© "any", æœ‰çš„ / yÇ’ude "some", æœ‰äº› / yÇ’uxiÄ“ "some", å¤š / duÅ "many", å°‘ / shÇo "few", å¹¾ / jÇ "several", è¨±å¤š / xÇ”duÅ "many", è‹¥å¹² / ruÃ²gÄn "few", å¤§éƒ¨åˆ† / dÃ bÃ¹fÃ¨n "the majority of", / å¤§é‡ dÃ liÃ ng "large quantity of", ä¸å°‘ / bÃ¹shÇo "not few", å¤šæ•¸ / duÅshÃ¹ "most" - Interrogative determiners - å“ª / nÇ "which", å“ªæ¨£ / nÇyÃ ng "which (kind/type/way)", ä»€éº¼ / shÃ©nme "what", ä½• / hÃ© "what", å¤šå°‘ / duÅshÇo "how many" - Other - ä¸Š / shÃ ng "the previous", ä¸‹ / xiÃ  "the next", å‰ / qiÃ¡n "the previous", å¾Œ / hÃ²u "the following", é ­ / tÃ³u "the first", å…¶é¤˜ / qÃ­yÃº "the rest", æŸ / mÇ’u "some, certain (singular)", æŸäº› / mÇ’uxiÄ“ "some, certain (plural)", å…¶ä»– / qÃ­tÄ "other", å¦ / lÃ¬ng "another", åŒ / tÃ³ng "the same"

PUNCT.content: Definition Punctuation marks are character groups used to delimit linguistic units in printed text. Punctuation is not taken to include logograms such as $, %, and Â§, which are instead tagged as SYM. Examples - Period: ã€‚ - Comma: ï¼Œ ã€ - Quotation marks: â€˜ â€™ â€œ â€ã€Œ ã€ ã€ ã€ - Title marks: ã€Š ã€‹

PRON.content: Definition Pronouns are words that substitute for nouns or noun phrases, whose meaning is recoverable from the linguistic or extralinguistic context. Some pronouns -- in particular certain demonstrative, total, indefinite, and interrogatives pronouns -- may also function as determiners (DET) and are tagged as such when functioning as a modifier of a noun. Examples - Personal pronouns - æˆ‘ / wÇ’ "I", ä½  / nÇ "you", å¦³ / nÇ "you (f.)", æ‚¨ / nÃ­n "you (polite)", ä»– / tÄ "he", å¥¹ / tÄ "she", "æ€¹" / tÃ¡n "he/she (polite)", ç¥‚ / tÄ "he (the God)", ç‰  / tÄ "it (other animals)", å®ƒ / tÄ "it(non-animate)", ä¹‹ / zhÄ« "it", æˆ‘å€‘ / wÇ’men "we", ä½ å€‘ / nÇmen "you (pl.)", å¦³å€‘ / nÇmen "you (f.pl.)", æ‚¨å€‘ / nÃ­nmen "you (pl. polite)", ä»–å€‘ / tÄmen "they", å¥¹å€‘ / tÄmen "they (f.)", ç‰ å€‘ / tÄmen "they (other animals)", å®ƒå€‘ / tÄmen "they (non-animate)", äººå®¶ / rÃ©njiÄ "others, other (people); he/she/it/they" - Reciprocal and reflexive pronouns - å½¼æ­¤ / bÇcÇ "each other", è‡ªèº« / zÃ¬shÄ“n "self", å·±èº« / jÇshÄ“n "self", è‡ªå·± / zÃ¬jÇ "self", æˆ‘è‡ªå·± / wÇ’zÃ¬jÇ "myself", ä½ è‡ªå·± / nÇzÃ¬jÇ "yourself", å¥¹å€‘è‡ªå·± / tÄmenzÃ¬jÇ "themselves (f.)", etc - Demonstrative pronouns - é€™ / zhÃ¨ "this", é€™äº› / zhÃ¨xiÄ“ "these", æ­¤ / cÇ "this", é‚£ / nÃ  "that", é‚£äº› / nÃ xiÄ“ "those" - Total pronouns - å…¨éƒ¨ / quÃ¡nbÃ¹ "all", ä¸€åˆ‡ / yÄ«qiÃ¨ "everything", æ‰€æœ‰ / suÇ’yÇ’u "all", å¤§å®¶ / dÃ jiÄ "everybody", å¤§ä¼™å…’ / _dÃ huÇ’r "everybody" - Indefinite pronouns - ä»»ä½• / rÃ¨nhÃ© "any", æœ‰çš„ / yÇ’ude "some", æœ‰äº› / yÇ’uxiÄ“ "some", å¾ˆå¤š / duÅ "many", å¾ˆå°‘ / shÇo "few", è¨±å¤š / xÇ”duÅ "many", è‹¥å¹² / ruÃ²gÄn "few", å¤§éƒ¨åˆ† / dÃ bÃ¹fÃ¨n "the majority", / å¤§é‡ dÃ liÃ ng "a large quantity", ä¸å°‘ / bÃ¹shÇo "not few", å¤šæ•¸ / duÅshÃ¹ "most", å¦å¤– / lÃ¬ngwÃ i "other(s)" (also ADV),Â å…¶ä»– / qÃ­tÄ "other(s)" - Locational pronouns - é€™è£¡ / zhÃ¨lÇ "here", é‚£è£¡ / nÃ lÇ "there" - Manner pronouns - é€™æ¨£(å­) / zhÃ¨yÃ ng(zi) "thus, this way, like this" (also ADV), é‚£æ¨£(å­) / nÃ yÃ ng(zi) "that way, like that" - Interrogative pronouns Â - èª° / shÃ©i "who", ä»€éº¼ / shÃ©nme "what", å¤šå°‘ / duÅshÇo "how many", å“ªè£¡ / nÇlÇ "where", å“ªæ¨£ ï¼ nÇyÃ ng "which kind/type/way", ä½•æ¨£ / hÃ©yÃ ng "what kind/type/way", æ€æ¨£ / zÄ›nyÃ ng "how" (also ADV) - Other - X + æ–¹: å°æ–¹ / duÃ¬fÄng "the other party", é›™æ–¹ / shuÄngfÄng "both parties", å·±æ–¹ / jÇfÄng "one's own side/party", ä¸€æ–¹ / yÄ«fÄng "one party", ä¸‰æ–¹ / sÄnfÄng "all three parties", etc. - X + è€…: å‰è€… / qiÃ¡nzhÄ› "the former", å¾Œè€… / hÃ²uzhÄ› "the latter", äºŒè€… / Ã¨rzhÄ› "the two", ä¸‰è€… / sÄnzhÄ› "the three", etc. - å…¶é¤˜ / qÃ­yÃº "the rest"

AUX.content:
Definition

An auxiliary is a word that accompanies the lexical verb of a verb phrase and expresses grammatical distinctions not carried by the lexical verb, such as person, number, tense, mood, aspect, and voice.

In Chinese, auxiliaries can be divided into modal and modal-like auxiliaries which are preverbal and do not have to be adjacent to the verb; copulae, in the narrow sense of pure linking words for nonverbal predication; and aspect markers, which must come immediately after the verb. Note that certain modal auxiliaries can also function as main verbs, usually when they have a direct object or full clausal complement.

Examples

- Modal and modal-like auxiliaries
  - can be pre-modified by the negator ä¸ / bÃ¹ but cannot take object and be post-modified by aspect marker
  - èƒ½ / nÃ©ng "be able to", æœƒ / huÃ¬ "will", å¯ä»¥ / kÄ›yÇ "can", æ‡‰è©² / yiÌ„nggaÌ„i "should", è‚¯ / kÄ›n "be willing to", æ•¢ / gÇn "dare", æœ‰ / yÇ’u (perfective), æ²’æœ‰ / mÃ©iyÇ’u (negative perfective)
- Aspect markers
  - äº† / le (perfective), è‘—/ç€ / zhe (durative), é / guo (experiential)
- Copulae
  - æ˜¯ / shÃ¬, ç‚º / wÃ©i

Delimitation

[work in progress]

CCONJ.content: Definition A coordinating conjunction is a word that links words or larger constituents without syntactically subordinating one to the other and expresses a semantic relationship between them. Examples - "and" - èˆ‡ / yÇ”, å’Œ / hÃ©, è·Ÿ / gÄ“n, åŒ / tÃ³ng, ä»¥åŠ / yÇjÃ­, ä¸¦ / bÃ¬ng, ä¸¦ä¸” / bÃ¬ngqiÄ›, è€Œ / Ã©r, è€Œä¸” / Ã©rqiÄ›, ä¸” / qiÄ› - Note that èˆ‡, å’Œ, è·Ÿ, åŒ may also function as prepositions (ADP) - "or" - æˆ– / huÃ², æˆ–è€… / huÃ²zhÄ›, é‚„æ˜¯ / hÃ¡ishÃ¬ - "but" - ä½† / dÃ n, ä½†æ˜¯ / dÃ nshÃ¬

X.content:
Definition

The tag X is used for words that for some reason cannot be assigned a real part-of-speech category. It should be used very restrictively. 

A special usage of X is for cases of code-switching where it is not possible (or meaningful) to analyze the intervening language grammatically (and where the dependency relation foreign is typically used in the syntactic analysis). This usage does not extend to ordinary loan words which should be assigned a normal part-of-speech.

Example

- ä»–çªç„¶èªªï¼šã€Œlkjwe ashwi oiucsã€ / tÄ tÅ«rÃ¡n shuÅï¼šã€Œlkjwe ashwi oiucsã€ "He suddenly said, 'lkjwe ashwi oiucs'."

SYM.content:
Definition

A symbol is a word-like entity that differs from ordinary words by form, function, or both.

Many symbols are or contain special non-alphanumeric, non-standard logographic characters, similarly to punctuation. What makes them different from punctuation is that they can be substituted by normal words. This involves all currency symbols, e.g. $75 is identical to ä¸ƒåäº”åœ“ / qÄ«shÃ­wÇ” yuÃ¡n "seventy-five dollars".

Mathematical operators form another group of symbols.

Another group of symbols is emoticons and emoji.

Examples

- ï¼„, ï¼…, Â§, Â©
- +, âˆ’, Ã—, Ã·, =, <, >
- :), ^\_^, ğŸ˜
- john.doe@universal.org, http://universaldependencies.org/, 1-800-COMPANY

NOUN.content: Definition Nouns are a part of speech typically denoting a person, place, thing, animal, or idea. The NOUN tag is intended for common nouns only. See PROPN for proper nouns and PRON for pronouns. As a special case, classifiers (é‡è© / liÃ ngcÃ­) are also tagged NOUN per UD guidelines. Their classifier status may be preserved in the feature column (FEATS) as NounType=Clf. Examples - Nouns - can form noun phrase by pre-modifying with a numeral and a classifier, like ä¸€æ¯æ°´ / yÄ«bÄ“ishÇ”i "a cup of water". - æ¯å­ï¼ bÄ“izi "cup", è‰ / cÇo "grass", æ°§æ°£ / yÇngqÃ¬ "oxygen", åœ°æ–¹ / dÃ¬fang "place", èƒ½åŠ› / nÃ©nglÃ¬ "ability", æ­·å² / lÃ¬shÇ "history" - Classifiers - can be pre-modified by both NUM and DET directly. - å€‹ / gÃ¨ (generic classifier), æ¢ / tiÃ¡o (classifier for long, slim objects), æœ¬ / bÄ›n (classifier for book-like objects), é›™ / shuÄng "pair", æ¯ / bÄ“i "cup (of something)", ç£… / bÃ ng "pound", å¹´ / niÃ¡n "year" - Temporal nouns - typically act as adjunct of verb phrases but can pre-modify another noun by adding a çš„ / de suffix. - ä»Šå¤© / jÄ«ntiÄn â€˜todayâ€™, å»å¹´ / qÃ¹niÃ¡n â€œlast yearâ€, æ™šä¸Š / wÇnshÃ ng â€œnightâ€ - Position words - typically act as object of directional verb, åœ¨ / zÃ i "at" but do not satisfy the requirements of PROPN and PRON. - æ—é‚Š / pÃ¡ngbiÄn "side", ä¸€æ— / yÄ«pÃ¡ng "aside" - Localizers - typically indicate spatial information and is used as a sentence constituent, like obj and obl. - è¥¿ / xÄ« "west"

VERB.content: Definition A verb is a member of the syntactic class of words that typically signal events and actions, can constitute a minimal predicate in a clause, and govern the number and types of other constituents which may occur in the clause. Typically, A verb can be pre-modified by the negator ä¸ / bÃ¹ except that those can be pre-modified by degree modifier like å¥½ / hÇo "very" are classified as ADJ. Despite its use in copular constructions, æ˜¯ / shÃ¬ "be" is tagged as a verb due to its other non-copular meanings and functions. Examples - æ¸¸æ³³ / yÃ³uyÇ’ng "swim" - è½ / tÄ«ng "listen" - å‘¼å¸ / hÅ«xÄ« "breathe" - å–œæ­¡ / xÇhuÄn "like" - æ±ºå®š / juÃ©dÃ¬ng "decide" - æœ‰ / yÇ’u "have; own; exist" - æ˜¯ / shÃ¬ "be; exist"

ADJ.content:
Definition

Adjectives are words that typically modify nouns and specify their properties or attributes. They may also function as predicates. These include the categories known as å€åˆ¥è© / qÅ«biÃ©cÃ­ and å½¢å®¹è© / xÃ­ngrÃ³ngcÃ­.

- å¥½ é¢¨æ™¯ / hÇo fÄ“ngjÇng "good scenery"
- å¤©æ°£ å¾ˆ å¥½ / tiÄnqÃ¬ hÄ›n hÇo "The weather is good."

The adjective may be accompanied by the particle çš„ / de when functioning as a prenominal modifier (for either å€åˆ¥è© / qÅ«biÃ©cÃ­ or å½¢å®¹è© / xÃ­ngrÃ³ngcÃ­), and obligatorily when functioning as a predicate if it is a å€åˆ¥è© / qÅ«biÃ©cÃ­. 

- ç¾éº— çš„ é¢¨æ™¯ / mÄ›ilÃ¬ de fÄ“ngjÇng "beautiful scenery"
- é€™ éš» é³¥ æ˜¯ é›Œ çš„ / zhÃ¨ zhÄ« niÇo shÃ¬ cÃ­ de "This bird is female." 

Note that ordinal numerals such as ç¬¬ä¸€ / dÃ¬yÄ« "first" and ç¬¬ä¸‰ / dÃ¬sÄn "third" are to be treated as adjectives and tagged ADJ per UD specifications, even though they are traditionally classified as numerals in Chinese.

Examples

- å½¢å®¹è© / xÃ­ngrÃ³ngcÃ­
  - typically can be pre-modified by degree adverbs, like å¥½ / hÇo "very", and the negator ä¸ / bÃ¹, can be post-modified by aspect markers, like äº† / le, but cannot take object.
  - å¥½ / hÇo "good", ç¾éº— / mÄ›ilÃ¬ "beautiful", å° / xiÇo "small", è€ / lÇo "old"
- å€åˆ¥è© / qÅ«biÃ©cÃ­
  - can pre-modify nouns directly and can be pre-modified by the negator é / fÄ“i but cannot be modified by degree adverbs.
  - é‡‘Â / jÄ«n "gold(en)", ç”· / nÃ¡n "male", æ…¢æ€§ / mÃ nxÃ¬ng "slow acting"
- Ordinal numbers
  - formed by a numerial preceded by ç¬¬ / dÃ¬.
  - ç¬¬ä¸€ / dÃ¬yÄ« "first", ç¬¬ä¸‰ / dÃ¬sÄn "third", ç¬¬äº”åä¸‰ / dÃ¬wÇ”shÃ­sÄn "fifty-third"

PART.content: Definition Particles are function words that must be associated with another word, phrase, or clause to impart meaning and that do not satisfy definitions of other universal parts of speech (such as ADP, AUX, CCONJ, or SCONJ). In Chinese, particles include the genitive/associative/relativizer/nominalizer marker çš„ / de; å¾— / de in V-å¾— extent/descriptive constructions (see compound:ext); the manner adverbializer åœ° / de; the "et cetera" markers ç­‰(ç­‰) / dÄ›ng(dÄ›ng); sentence-final particles (å¥æœ«åŠ©è© / jÃ¹muÃ² zhÃ¹cÃ­); and the object relativizer æ‰€ / suÇ’. Examples - Genitive çš„ - ç‹— çš„ å°¾å·´ ï¼ gÇ’u de wÄ›ibÄ "a dog's tail" - Associative çš„ - é«˜èˆˆ çš„ å­©å­ / gÄoxÃ¬ng de hÃ¡izi "happy children" - Relativizer çš„ - èµ°è·¯ çš„ äºº ï¼ zÇ’ulÃ¹ de rÃ©n "people who are walking" - Nominalizer çš„ - åƒ ä¸ å®Œ çš„ ä¸ å‡† èµ° ï¼ chÄ« bÃ¹ wÃ¡n de bÃ¹ zhÇ”n zÇ’u "those who don't finish eating aren't allowed to go" - Extent/descriptive å¾— Â - ä»– è·‘ å¾— å¾ˆ å¿« ï¼tÄ pÇo de hÄ›n kuÃ i "He runs very fast." - Adverbializer åœ° - ä»– æ…¢æ…¢ åœ° è·‘ ï¼ tÄ mÃ nmÃ n de pÇo "He's running slowly." - Etc. marker - é€™è£¡ æœ‰ æ¢¨å­ï¼Œæ©˜å­ï¼Œç­‰ç­‰ ï¼ zhÃ¨lÇ yÇ’u lÃ­zi, jÃºzi, dÄ›ngdÄ›ng "There are pears, oranges, etc. here." - Sentence-final particles - ä½  æƒ³ å» å— ï¼Ÿ ï¼ nÇ xiÇng qÃ¹ ma "Do you want to go?" - æˆ‘å€‘ ä¸€èµ· å» å§ ï¼ wÇ’men yÄ«qÇ qÃ¹ ba "Let's go together." - ä»– åª æ˜¯ ä¸€ å€‹ äºº è€Œå·² ï¼ tÄ zhÇ shÃ¬ yÄ« gÃ¨ rÃ©n Ã©ryÇ "He's just one person." - ä»–å€‘ ä¸€å®š ä¾† çš„ ï¼ tÄmen yÄ«dÃ¬ng lÃ¡i de "They will definitely come." - Object relativizer æ‰€ - ä»– æ‰€ æˆ´ çš„ å¸½å­ / tÄ suÇ’ dÃ i de mÃ ozi "the hat that he wears"

INTJ.content: Definition An interjection is a word that is used most often as an exclamation or part of an exclamation. It typically expresses an emotional reaction, is not syntactically related to other accompanying expressions, and may include a combination of sounds not otherwise found in the language. Note that words primarily belonging to another part of speech retain their original category when used in exclamations. For example, æ˜¯ï¼ / shÃ¬ "Yes!" would still be tagged VERB. Onomatopoeic words (æ“¬è²è© / nÇshÄ“ngcÃ­) should only be treated as interjections if they are used as an exclamation (e.g., å–µï¼ / miÄo "Meow!"), otherwise they should be tagged according to their syntactic function in context (often as adverbs in Chinese, e.g., ä»–å€‘å˜°å˜°å–³å–³åœ°èŠå¤© / tÄmen jÄ«jizhÄzhÄ de liÃ¡otiÄn "They chat jijizhazha-ly (i.e., lively, noisily, etc.)."). Examples - å“¦ / Ã³ - å“å“Ÿ / ÄiyÅ - å—¨ / hÄi - æ¬¸ / Äi

ADP.content: Definition The Chinese ADP covers three categories of function words analyzed as adpositions: (1) "coverbs"/prepositions, (2) valence markers, and (3) "localizers"/postpositions. Chinese coverbs introduce an extra participant/argument to the event/main verb in a clause (but note that many coverbs may also function as main verbs). - ä»– å° æˆ‘ åš äº† å¾ˆ æ®˜å¿ çš„ äº‹æƒ… ï¼ tÄ duÃ¬ wÇ’ zuÃ² le hÄ›n cÃ¡nrÄ›n de shÃ¬qÃ­ng "He did some cruel things to me." Valence markers such as the "disposal" æŠŠ / bÇ and the "long passive" è¢« / bÃ¨i (when followed by an agent noun) are also tagged ADP (however, the "short passive" è¢« / bÃ¨i when not followed by a noun should be tagged AUX). - ä½  æŠŠ å®ƒ åƒ æ‰ å§ / nÇ bÇ tÄ chÄ« diÃ o ba "You should eat it up." - æˆ‘ è¢« ä»– æ‰“ äº† ä¸€ é “ / wÇ’ bÃ¨i tÄ dÇle yÄ« dÃ¹n "I was given a beating by him." Localizers (also known as æ–¹ä½è© / faÌ„ngwÃ¨icÃ­) serving as postpositions, typically indicate spatial information in relation to the noun preceding it. Some localizers have also grammaticalized into clausal markers indicating temporal information. Localizers with the clausal function are still tagged as ADP (but are labeled with the dependency relation mark). Note that when localizers are serving as a sentence constituent, like obj and obl, they should be tagged as NOUN. - æˆ‘ æŠŠ æ¢¨å­ æ”¾ åœ¨ æ¡Œå­ ä¸Š / wÇ’ bÇ lÃ­zi fÃ ng zÃ i zhuÅzi shÃ ng "I'm putting the pears on the table." - ä»– å¦»å­ æ­» äº† ä¹‹å¾Œ ï¼Œ ä»– ä¹Ÿ ä¸ æƒ³ æ´» äº† / tÄ qÄ«zi sÇ le zhÄ«hÃ²u, tÄ yÄ› bÃ¹xiÇng huÃ³ le "After his wife died, he no longer wants to live either." Examples - Coverbs / prepositions - åœ¨ / zÃ i "in, on, at", å° / duÃ¬ "to, toward", è·Ÿ / gÄ“n "with" (comitative), ç”¨ / yÃ²ng "with" (instrumental), ç‚ºäº† / wÃ¨ile "for (sake of)" - Valence markers - æŠŠ / bÇ (disposal), å°‡ / jiÄng (disposal), è¢« / bÃ¨i (long passive only) - Postpositions - (ä¹‹)ä¸Š / (zhÄ«)shÃ ng "above", (ä»¥)ä¸‹ / (yÇ)xiÃ  "below, beneath", å…§ / nÃ¨i "inside", å¾Œ / hÃ²u "behind; after", å‰ / qiÃ¡n "in front; before", ä¸­ / zhÅng "in the middle; during", æ™‚ / shÃ­ "during"

NUM.content: Definition A numeral is a word, functioning most typically as a determiner, a pronoun or an adjective, that expresses a number and a relation to the number, such as quantity, sequence, frequency or fraction. Cardinal numerals are covered by NUM regardless of syntactic function and regardless of whether they are expressed as words (äº” / wÇ” "five") or digits (5). By contrast, ordinal numerals are always tagged ADJ. Examples - 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 100, 10,358, 5.23, 3/4 - ä¸€ / yÄ« "one", äºŒ / Ã¨r "two", ä¸‰ / sÄn "three", ä¸€ç™¾ / yÄ«bÇi "one hundred", äº”åå…­ / wÇ”shÃ­liÃ¹ "fifty-six", ä¸€è¬ä¸‰ç™¾äº”åå…« / yÄ«wÃ nsÄnbÇiwÇ”shÃ­bÄ "ten thousand three hundred and fifty-eight", å››åˆ†ä¹‹ä¸‰ / sÃ¬fÄ“nzhÄ«sÄn "three-quarters"

ADV.content: Definition Adverbs (å‰¯è© / fÃ¹cÃ­) typically modify verbs, adjectives, and other adverbs for such categories as time, manner, degree, frequency, or negation. - ä½ Â æ…¢æ…¢/ADV èªª/VERB / nÇ mÃ nman shuÅ "Speak slowly." - å¥¹ éå¸¸/ADV å¿«æ¨‚/ADJ / tÄ fÄ“ichÃ¡ng kuÃ ilÃ¨ "She is extremely happy." - ä»–å€‘ å¾ˆ/ADV æ—©/ADV èµ·ä¾†/VERB / tÄmen hÄ›n zÇo qÇlÃ¡i "They get up very early." Some adverbs also modify clauses with conjunctive and discursive functions. - ä»– å» æ²’æœ‰ è·Ÿ æˆ‘ èª¬ / tÄ quÃ¨ mÃ©iyÇ’u gÄ“n wÇ’ shuÅ "He didn't tell me, however." - ä»Šå¤© ç•¶ç„¶ æ²’ äºº å•Š ï¼ jÄ«ntiÄn dÄngrÃ¡n mÃ©i rÃ©n a "Of course nobody's here today." A small number of adverbs may also modify numerals and determiners, or nouns and pronouns. - å·®ä¸å¤š äº”åƒ / chÃ bÃ¹duÅ wÇ”qiÄn "almost five thousand" - é€£ ä»– éƒ½ ä¸ å» äº† / liÃ¡n tÄ dÅu bÃ¹ qÃ¹ le "Even he's not going." There is a closed subclass of pronominal adverbs that refer to circumstances in context, rather than naming them directly; similarly to pronouns, these can be categorized as interrogative, demonstrative, etc. These should be treated as adverbs when modifying a predicate, but otherwise some of them can function as a nominal in the syntax, in which case they should be tagged PRON. - ä½  ç‚ºä»€éº¼ ä¸ ä¾† / nÇ wÃ¨ishÃ©nme bÃ¹ lÃ¡i "Why aren't you coming?" - æˆ‘ é€™æ¨£ åš çš„ / wÇ’ shÃ¬ zhÃ¨yÃ ng zuÃ² de "I do it like this." Note that although some adverbs express temporal information, many common time expressions (e.g., ä»Šå¤© / jÄ«ntiÄn 'today', å»å¹´ / qÃ¹niÃ¡n "last year", æ™šä¸Š / wÇnshÃ ng "night") are actually nouns and should be tagged NOUN. Those temporal nouns can pre-modify another noun by adding a çš„ / de suffix but adverbs cannot. Examples - Manner adverbs - æ…¢æ…¢ / mÃ nman "slowly", äº’ç›¸ ï¼ hÃ¹xiÄng "mutually" - Temporal, aspectual, and modal adverbs - å³å°‡ / jÃ­jiÄng "about to", å°‡ / jiÄng "will", (æ­£)åœ¨ / (zhÃ¨ng)zÃ i "in progress", å¯§å¯ / nÃ¬ngkÄ› "would rather", å¯èƒ½ / kÄ›nÃ©ng "possibly" (NB: also ADJ "possible" and NOUN "possibility") - Conjunctive adverbs - æ‰€ä»¥ / suÇ’yÇ "therefore", å» / quÃ¨ "however", ä¾‹å¦‚ / lÃ¬rÃº "for example", ç„¶å¾Œ / rÃ¡nhÃ²u "afterwards", é‚£ / nÃ  "then; in that case", å°± / jiÃ¹ "then; as a result" - Frequency and duration adverbs - ç¶“å¸¸ / jÄ«ngchÃ¡ng "often", ä¸€ä¸‹ / yÄ«xiÃ  "once; for a little while", å¤šæ¬¡ / duÅcÃ¬ "many times" - Negation adverbs - ä¸ / bÃ¹ "not", æœª / wÃ¨i "not yet", æ°¸ä¸ / yÇ’ngbÃ¹ "never" - Numeral-modifying adverbs - å¤§æ¦‚ / dÃ gÃ i "approximately", å·®ä¸å¤š / chÃ bÃ¹duÅ "almost", ä¸è¶³ / bÃ¹zÃº "less than", è‡³å°‘ / zhÃ¬shÇo "at least", æœ€å¤š / zuÃ¬duÅ "at most" - Noun-modifying adverbs - é€£ / liÃ¡n "even", åˆ / yÃ²u "another" - Pronominal adverbs - æ€æ¨£ / zÄ›nyÃ ng "how", é€™æ¨£ / zhÃ¨yÃ ng "this way, like this, thus", é‚£éº¼ / nÃ me "so", ç‚ºä»€éº¼ / wÃ¨ishÃ©nme "why" - Other - éƒ½ / dÅu "also; all", ä¹Ÿ / yÄ› "also", æ‰ / cÃ¡i "then and only then", è¶Šä¾†è¶Š yuÃ¨lÃ¡iyuÃ¨ "more and more", ç•¶ç„¶ / dÄngrÃ¡n "of course", é›£é“ / nÃ¡ndÃ o "could/must it be that...?" - "for example", "such as": æ¯”å¦‚ / bÇrÃº, æ¯”å¦‚èªª / bÇrÃºshuÅ, ä¾‹å¦‚ / lÃ¬rÃº, è­¬å¦‚ / pÃ¬rÃº, - "like": åƒ / xiÃ ng (note this can also function as a main verb; an example of the adverbial usage is åƒä»–æ˜¨å¤©èªª... / xiÃ ng tÄ zuÃ³tiÄn shuÅ "Like he said yesterday...")

PROPN.content:
Definition

A proper noun is a noun (or nominal content word, or substantive) that is the name (or part of the name) of a specific individual, place, or object. Syntactically a proper noun cannot be preceded by numerals and classifiers but a common noun can. For institutional names that have clear internal structure and contain regular words belonging to other parts of speech such as nouns (e.g., å…¬å¸ / gÅngsÄ« "company", å¤§å­¸ / dÃ xuÃ© "university", etc.), those words should be segmented as their own tokens and still tagged their native part of speech; only the proper nouns in such complex names should be tagged PROPN.

Examples

- å­”å­ / kÇ’ngzÇ "Confucius"
- äºæ´² / yÃ zhÅu "Asia"
- å¨å¨ æœ¨æ å…¬å¸ ï¼ wÄ“iwÄ“i mÃ¹cÃ¡i gÅngsÄ« "Weiwei Timber Company"
